Without mentionning the story pacing, the story and lore would've really beneficiated from an M rating. People underestimate this rating and it goes way beyond blood splatting and gore. See Wall Market and the prostitution + sex slavery themes that the arc talks about? Or Cloud's PTSD events? Shinra's immoral research on humans? All those strong themes really suffered from being talked under a T rating and really deserved to be explained with a mature and unrestricted perspective. When you talk about such themes, you don't take gloves as if your public is composed of teenagers because the original FF7 was geared towards a more mature audience. Now, the story pacing also suffered from all the unnecessary events and subquests that have been added to stretch out the playtime because Midgar's arc in the original only lasted 30 minutes. But fortunately, it really gets insanely better towards the end when the game really throws you epic moments after epic moments with nearly no pause at all. But still, the story pacing could have been avoided if the game was complete and tried to stick more to the original story as Nomura suggested (Whispers weren't his ideas). At the end of the day, if you're not too picky, you'll go easily through the pacing and T rating, especially with how insane and cinematic the mise-en-scene is, how fun the combats are and how full of life is Midgar (though imo, Midgar's life should have been a bit toned down in terms of mood because in the original game, the city was described as really dark and depressive where the people were not as happy as in Remake).

Ever since I first played FF7 on PS1, I was hooked on the FF series, so I knew, that I'm gonna have to take my sweet time playing this game. With this being a reimagined and modernized version of the game, I sadly can not NOT compare this to the original FF as I write this. Obviously, graphically it is far superior to the original version, but that was the only aspect, that exceeded the original. The game struggled with the FF XIII tube-like world system - in OG FF 7, the world felt massive and open to explore (Yes, I do get that this isn't the full FF7 experience yet - the stroy continues) but this game is built the same way FF XIII was (My least favourite of the franchise so far) You watch a pretty cinematic (and they are pretty!) then you wander into a tube-like world with no real freedom to explore, mostly getting from point A to B. Then there is a bossfight and then you do it all over again. Luckily the delivery of this system is well polished and if you like games for their stories - this one is for you. I do have to wonder though, if I've never played original FF7, would I even have any idea what is going on most of the game or who is this Sephiroth dude, that just drops haikus and leaves mysteriously half of the times. I know I started the review on a bit negative undertone, but I actually did love my playthrough. It just can't compete with the original game experience, and that is fine. Pick it up if you are a FF fan - you will love it!

I have a love hate for this game. I was a teen when this game originally released and I loved it. I realized now that the story is still great and relevant but the gameplay in this version is flawed if not broken in some battles. I prefer the original only because this was a bad execution of the active RPG mechanic. Grinding isn't really a thing you can do but it feels very necessary and even if you try it's far more time consuming than before. Weapons, items, and accessories feel really useless throughout most of the game. I feel like the game heavily relies on its active battle mechanic but too many enemies have long portions where you just wait for your bar to fill and use magic. It always seemed like I spent too much time managing which materia and equips I had instead of playing which is kind of expected for an RPG but annoying for an active RPG. There's no quick swap for loadouts and that's just a huge fail. Some standard enemy battles are way harder than boss battles. A few points had just a group of enemies that somehow wiped the floor with my team. Ones with grapples are the worst. The dodge time is incredibly specific and you can't block them. The enemies later in the game will almost always focus on the character you're playing which causes you to constantly jump around. I had moments where 4 enemies would team up and just do perpetual damage and grabs to every character I had control of. It was terrible. I still love the story. The voice acting is pretty good. The graphics look great and I rarely ran into any problems with the game as long as you keep it in performance mode. Graphics mode is choppy and slow, almost unplayable. The quality improvement is marginal so keep it in performance. All in all I like it but you can tell this was made by people who understand RPG first and active action battle last. The worst part of battle is that you can use a spell or ability and it can be canceled by any enemy at any time doing an attack on you. At some parts of the game this happening once or twice can mean you are going to run out of HP.

Good game, but definitely overrated and way inferior than the original. It is also not a "remake", but a "reboot" or a "reimagining" of FFVII, with important changes in the story. It is also important to note that this is not the whole experience, but the 1st part of what it might become a trilogy. Technically its a marvel, and the OST is one of the best of all time. However, none of this is important considering the game that it "remakes". Everything that is taken from the original game stands out, amd few elements are even improved (more screentime for secondary characters gives depth). But unfortunately, many elements have been either dragged on (to infinity) or dumbed down. Story changes aside (there are many, specially towards the end, but they are kinda subjective), the lenght of the game is artificially increased by adding terrible secondary tasks and making irrelevant areas longer (destroyed highway or Hojo's lab for example). Combat is way less strategic than the original, and battles get repetitive even against bosses (some of them can take up to 30min). The camera is also bad, and we are often unable to tell what is even happening, specially with lots of enemies, flying foes or huge bosses. Summonings are great, but they don't appear many times. Overall, less challenging and deep than the old turn-based system. The PS5 version is definitely the way to go, as 60fps and improved loading times are a gamechanger. The DLC is nice (a bit too short though) and introduces the old character of Yuffie to this new version of the story. Good game but drastically overrated just because of its name.

FINAL FANTASY VII REMAKE INTERGRADE (PS5) "The New Standard for all Remakes/Remasters" (+) Presentation (+) Characters (+) Performance (+) Combat FFVIIR features some of the most breathtaking characters, material quality, and environments to date. The presentation excels that of most AAA games and is nearly incomparable to its original. Characters are likable, relatable, and brought to life as I became well invested in their adventures throughout the game. Although it’s not a 'new' feature as it leans heavily on its original material, it is still executed well here. Performance is outstanding as the game is extremely well developed as I experienced no bugs, crashes, or glitches throughout all my playthroughs. The combat in this game can either be overwhelming or simplistic depending on the difficulty you play at. I recommend at least trying the hard difficulty (unlocked after first playthrough) because it encourages you to plan your attacks, Materia use, and ability use. Its real time strategy reimagined in a tactical modern-day age and executed to near perfection. (-) Traversal (-) Finale (-) UI/UX Extremely outdated traversal as it is easily the worst part about this game. Slow walking, numerous cutscenes, and linear corridors interrupt the flow of the game in nearly every one of the 18 chapters. The Yuffie DLC aims to get rid of these annoyances by allowing you to sprint more frequently and glide through traversal puzzles more enjoyably. The ending of the main game has been controversial to a lot of people, but I appreciate the effort to try something new when compared to the original. The game earns its remake title instead of a remaster. However, the last 2 chapters of this game are very repetitive and frustrating in terms of gameplay. New characters are being introduced with not enough impact on gameplay and the combat begins to fade into a grind. The user interface is inept, especially the pause menu. There are way too many hidden options buried inside unnecessary menus (i.e. why is the ‘Upgrade Weapons’ menu in its own section? Just pair it with the Materia and Equipment section since all your stats and characters are shown there. Why is chapter selection hidden in the system menu? Why is the map so underwhelming and frustrating to navigate when traversing areas with different floors or height levels? etc…). (3/5) - Above Average - Recommended at $59.99

While this game's visuals and technical quality carry over from the original, so do the original deficiencies. Not only does it flows over, but it's heightened here because this 4-6 hour add-on is a rip-off for the asking price of $20. I made the argument with the original that Square Enix really wanted to turn the remake game into an interactive movie, and that's full-on display with Intermission. The actual game mechanics here in intermission are a redundant, pointless addition. Combat in ff7r, on the whole, is redundant. None of it adds anything to the package that Square Enix made here. Controlling characters from one objective to the next could be reduced by half and instead be infused into narrative cutscenes, and nothing would be lost. Having Yuffie play Fort Condor against other people was boring and redundant and could have just been a narrative cutscene, and nothing would have been lost. Even the majority of exploring the Shinra HQ could have easily been filled in by having cutscenes, and nothing would have changed. And that's the biggest problem with the project; so much of the game has a "Game" forced into a story-driven retelling. And it's here solely because if they had made this into an episodic interactive movie, the base would have flipped out. But instead of trying to make their vision into a game, they stubbornly went forward with their initial idea and jammed in a half-baked "Game." Intermission suffers immensely from this hamfisting the stilted game mechanics from the base while reusing an absurd amount of assets and then charging you $20 for the privilege! Does Yuffie's chapter add anything? Combat and game-wise? Nothing. Narratively? Plenty, but in the actual campaign and the ending scenes. But was that worth the cost you had to pay? Not even close. This should have been FREE for owners of the deluxe edition and at a maximum of $5 for everyone else. This chapter effectively turned a $60 game into an $80 game, and nothing about it warrants the cost. This doesn't bode well for the series, as the rest will obviously have to follow suit (as this is a singular game). I wish Square would admit they really don't care about making video games and instead go ahead and start focusing on their real vision of user-controlled interactive movies. This middle-of-the-road approach hampers everything.

While this game boasts incredible visuals, detailed animations, and intense action sequences, I found myself conflicted about the overall experience. The storyline is where it fell short for me. Character deaths often felt unnecessary, and many of the protagonists made decisions that were difficult to relate to, which ultimately made it hard to connect with or care about their outcomes.Narrative direction aside, I also felt that some themes were overemphasized in a way that disrupted immersion. I have no issue with the inclusion of diverse characters, including LGBTQ+ representation, but at times it seemed forced or overly prevalent, particularly in emotional scenes that already struggled with subtlety. Characters like Ellie and the addition of Lilly, a trans character, could have added depth, but their arcs occasionally felt more like messaging than organic storytelling.Furthermore, the portrayal of nearly every female character with some form of emotional instability or trauma felt unbalanced and, at times, **** the end, while I appreciated the technical mastery of the game, the narrative left me feeling detached. For players more interested in cohesive and grounded storytelling, this installment might not resonate. Personally, finishing the game felt more like a relief than a reward, and I’m uncertain about continuing with the series should future entries maintain the same direction.

Players didn't get what they expected, so they won't buy the game—it's that simple. No one is obligated to like the story. They chose the child of some random NPC that no one even knew. I don't think they specifically picked the doctor; the chosen person could have just as easily been the child of any random bandit we killed in the previous **** problem is that, for players, this story was about Ellie and Joel. Neil knew this very well, which is why he put Joel in the most important parts of the trailer. We wanted to play as him because we had already built empathy for him in the first game—we accepted him with his rights and wrongs. We also saw Ellie as our daughter.What does this game give you, brother? Why should I care about the doctor’s daughter? We killed tons of people already because they were going to kill Ellie. Everything before that was just about survival. Why am I forced to empathize with Abby? If the game is about revenge, then why am I forgiving this girl at the end? What about the hundreds of people we killed just to reach this woman? All of it is dismissed just because of a brief Joel flashback?And what about Joel directly saying his name before dying? Isn't that completely out of character? What happened to the cautious man we knew? How did he suddenly soften up and trust complete strangers? The reason is obvious—Neil Druckmann’s collaboration with Anita Sarkeesian.Look, the game even includes a whole backstory for why a trans character is trans. Who the hell cares? We waited seven years, got hyped with the trailers, and it all turned out to be a lie. Lying bastard Neil.

Retcon job with a slow paced an uncompelling story. The original game was a full story in itself, this sequel us redundant. In the original draft of the story Druckmann wrote, someone trekking hundreds of miles and brooding on revenge, in a post-apocalyptic world, was an integral part of the story. This idea of Druck was rectified into not being part of the story. Saner voices prevailed, and we got a great game out of it. People who made necessary amendments and rectifications to the original story, were not part of the team that developed the second game. Neil Druckmann got to tell his poor version of the story. Stay clear of it.

Yeah, The Last of Us Part II was a complete disaster in terms of storytelling. It took everything that made the first game so compelling—its emotional depth, nuanced characters, and masterful pacing—and threw it out the window in favor of shock value and forced social commentary. The decision to brutally kill off Joel so early, and in such an unceremonious way, felt like an intentional gut punch to longtime fans rather than a meaningful plot development. The entire revenge arc felt hollow, especially when the game forced you to play as Abby and tried to make you sympathize with her after everything she did. It was like the game was punishing players for caring about Joel and **** then there’s the Fireflies, a supposedly major faction that gets wiped out as if they were nothing. The story just felt rushed and careless, prioritizing subverting expectations over delivering a strong, well-crafted narrative.This wasn’t a sequel—it was a misguided attempt to push a social media-fueled agenda, stripping power away from the original creators and replacing their vision with something that catered to trends rather than storytelling. It could have been great, but instead, it turned into a frustrating, disappointing mess.

Well, what's to be said that hasn't already been said, eh? The game was leaked with negative reception at what was to come. Deceitful advertising and pleas of open-mindedness from Neil himself. I don't care about Abby, Lev, or any of the other forgetful cast members that were throwaway characters with one-dimensional personalities. Ellie lost all the personality that made her memorable in the first game, and I don't think it necessitates mentioning how the writers felt about Joel given how quickly they dispatched him in the plot. The only reason my score is a 1 and not a 0 is because of the efforts of the teams that put together the spectacle that was the world itself. It's beautiful, the animations are amazing, and the combat is visceral. Such a shame the talent for this visual spectacle was wasted on this poor excuse for a game. Oh well, Neil got to make his revenge story game and that's all that matters to him, and used identity politics as a shield for bad writing and story decisions. Clearly I'm just a homophobic, sexist, transphobic bigot who can't stand to see a glorious work of modern art for what it is. 1/10 Neil. Do better.

The Last of Us 2 boasts some of the most impressive visuals and motion-capture acting in any video game. Indeed, it sets the bar for the latter. The game itself, however, is too often an after-thought next to the poorly constructed story. The player has zero agency: you will spend the vast majority of this terribly paced 30-hour campaign walking-and-talking or watching a cut-scene. Which brings us to the key issue with TLoU 2, the narrative. The story goes out of its way to not only reframe the events of the first game to fit a particular narrative, but to assassinate the original protagonists. The central theme is laughably simplistic, heavy-handed, and at no point examined critically. In the few brief moments where one is reminded of the brilliance of the original, it only evokes frustration and resentment at the knowledge that this game actively rejects and even undermines its predecessor. I cannot recommend this game to anyone, least of all those who hold the first Last of Us in high regard.

*score is only for the new stuff* The new content is interesting i guess, but still very little in this remaster justifies it being a new game that costs at least $10. Higher resolution and draw distance should've been available witht the PS5 patch for the original version that added better loading times and FPS. The skins are good, but even those aren't worth as much as they're charging. Everything else that was added is very low effort and just makes this remaster a cash grab: the lost levels are untouched from when they were removed while No Return is just a mini game with copy-paste content from the actual game. None of the added characters have their own models, they're just skins pasted over Ellie and Abby's movements. It also just recycles Factions content, again something that wasn't worked on for this remaster. The mode is also very underwhelming compared to how they were marketing it, and how cheaply it's put together is not what players should get from a company with Naughty Dog's reputation. For these reasons I can't give it higher than a 4; the resolution and draw distance improvements are the most worthwhile things about it, and maybe the skins if you like cosmetics in games, but even those aren't something that warrant a completely new game to be made, they're regular updates and $2-3 DLC at best.

Absolutely terrible, a complete cash grab. Left Behind is a half-baked attempt at a roguelike that really shows how stale Part II's gameplay was at launch. Dodging is utterly broken, you sway around like a drunken sailor when you aim, and there isn't much difference between characters besides a few differing stats. The game itself looks exactly like the ps4 version, you'd need a microscope to try and spot the differences. As for the game itself it's a tedious 30 hours with one of the most poorly written, convoluted plots in gaming. Not only does it radically retcon its source material it actively tries to insult the audience's intelligence. Characters gain and lose their abilities as the plot requires, huge distances of hostile territory are covered instantly (Jackson to Seattle is something like 20k miles, so 40k round trip), and characters will make choices they never would have in the first game ("hi, total strangers, my name's Joel!") Then there's the wokeness. Oh god, the wokeness. Maybe this was considered avant garde in 2019 but in 2023 the themes and ideas feel like they were generated by a far-left AI. Gay romance, transgenderism, musclebound women, all the male characters being either disposable or irredeemably evil - you'll love this game if you're a brainwashed leftist. All of this comes at the cost of the story which is told by people who desperately need to go back to school. It takes a hardline on "revenge" and pushes characters to extremes that just aren't believable and in the end it all feels hollow and trite. This is a game that tries to coast by on appearances - the twisted expression of horror and anger on a character's face is simply a mask that hides nothing underneath. The people peering into the blackness of this game in search of deeper meaning won't find any - it's the proverbial black cat in a windowless, dark room. Neil Druckmann is an artist with a minimum of skill and a maximum of pretension and it oozes out of every muddled, overacted scene, convoluted flashback, and cheap gimmick to try and persuade the audience to "see the other side" of a conflict. An utter and thorough failure.

The Last of Us Part 2 "Remastered" is, pound for pound, the most pointless remake/remaster in the history of video game remakes and remasters. Considering the original game is still a recent enough memory for most gamers, and with how polarizing it was, was it really a great idea to "remaster" this game? Aside from slightly nicer visuals, what does Part 2 "Remastered" really do to justify that price point? One new game mode, but another promised mode that is now cancelled. If you own this game still on PS4, then the PS5 upgrade is pointless aside from one new mode. The PS5 upgrade should have been free if you own the original game, but it isn't. Considering you can buy Last of Us Part 2 on PS4 for cheaper from legitimate retailers, both physical and digital, it makes you truly question why this "remaster" was made, and if it even should have happened in the first place? While I might not be too far in GOW Ragnarök, at least Santa Monica Studios had the decency to respect their fans, by making their roguelike mode a free DLC, and acting as a continuation to the story. Naughty Dog, on the other hand, charge you more for the same game (though a very slightly nicer looking one) and one new game mode. Skip this pointless "remaster". Even if it ends up free on PS Plus, it's not worth it if you've already played/beaten the original Last of Us Part 2. 0/10, for the pointlessness, lack of meaningful additions to this supposed "remaster", and for having the gall to actually charge even a penny for the same game.

One of the worst and most boring games I've ever played.I don't know anything about tabletop games or dungeons and dragons and I never liked turn based games. The only reason I wanted to play this game was from hearing about it so much, so much praise, and so many awards and people talking about it, how it's called one of the best games ever and how it's 96 rated on metacritic. I also played hundreds of games and I love any game that gives you freedom of choice and multiple approaches and consequences to your actions and different endings...I've played about 3 hours Baldur's Gate 3 and then I uninstalled. I'll explain why I think it's one of the worst games I've played:1- The Combat: This is the main and biggest reason why I absolutely hated the game, so you walk around freely in the game like any rpg and encounter quests and characters and chests and whatnot, but then whenever you encounter enemies the entire world literally pauses around you and it becomes a 1999 tabletop game that some nerdy kids in some basement play, it actually turns into Raid Shadow Legends lmao, it's actually hilarious that so many people like it, I guess stupidity knows no limits when it comes to the video game industry. And so it basically kills any momentum and the combat becomes this dice game where you click on an enemy and then your character attacks them and it either misses or hits, so you're not playing the game using your skills or your moves, it's just a dice game. This game is where I vowed to never ever buy or download games based on reputation and reviews, I have to watch a long playthrough in order to decide to get it or not.2- Everything All At Once: One of the other reasons why I uninstalled the game and stopped playing is because of how much convoluted stuff is in the game from the very start, like 30 different attacks or items in one character, this with 2 turns and it turns this to that for 10 turns and this attack isn't actually an attack and this move makes you hide and that move is a flame that heals and that move is some spell that turns enemies into jelly or makes them scared... It's just soooo much that I went "what the f**k is going in, what's all of this s**t?!". I know some games doesn't hold your hand but this is just a horrible terrible game that basically excepts you to be a Baldur's Gate player for 20 years and also have played the tabletop games, it's insanely dreadful for new players and I'm actually shocked that so many people new to the game with the IQ of 2 managed to like the game so much.3- The Story From The Start Is Not Interesting: The game starts with tentacle monsters and dragons and multiple race creatures and different worlds and so many things happening at once that I just literally lost interest from the start. The beginning **** or a in my opinion is the most important part to me, If from the start you're bored and uninteresting because of how much stuff is happening it's a bad game/movie. Games should have a clear beginning where you build up to things and slowly learn what this and that is, this game feels like you're dropped in the third act **** where you're already unlocked it all and so much story already happened, it doesn't feel like a new game that you start.

Disappointing. I so badly want to like this game: I love D&D, I love RPGs where your choices have big impacts, I love games where your party has growth. But this game is a huge miss. I've reached the end of the game and I've yet to play for an hour without experiencing a bug that was at best extremely frustrating and at worst (and frequently) game breaking. The pacing is horrible. There's an immediate sense of urgency in the main quest but you're also given a huge amount of side quests immediately, some of which are time sensitive. Side treks linger on for far longer than feels natural. And then, in Act2, the game suddenly becomes incredibly linear with only two point of significant interest. It feels rushed, feels sloppy, feels like it was in "early access" for too **** writing is boring. It's as if someone read a few D&D rule books and said "Yes I want to cram all of this in here."The companions are uninspired and templated. Here is all origin companions: "I was very powerful, but the bug in my head has me at level 1. I am a slave to XYZ, my quest is to secure my freedom from them. Along the way you can make the binary choice of me being a good guy or a bad guy."The game gives you access to all the creative tools of D&D, but punishes out of the box solutions and forces you into a linear or binary choice which is sometimes not even hinted at. For example (keeping it vague for spoilers), there was an encounter where an NPC was trapped on a cart full of explosive oil with a flammable trail of liquid leading to him and some hostile NPCs set the liquid on fire. I threw water at the fire around the cart, it exploded and he died. Reload. I run up and help/talk to him, it exploded and he died. Reload. I quickly kill all enemies in one round, it exploded and he died. Reload. I throw water on the flammable liquid trail before the encounter starts. Fire doesn't reach him! ...until the second round where the other half of the trail randomly catches fire with no interaction from any characters. Reload. I use a telekinesis spell to move the captive NPC to safety, he randomly teleports back to the location he was in but now he's prone and hostile. Reload. Googled a solution. Apparently you have to shoot the chair he's sitting on? Are you serious? Nothing ever indicated that solution, and any of the previous solutions should have worked, but this game won't allow creative thinking. There are numerous examples of instances where you're able to withhold info from NPCs, but then they suddenly have the info as if you told them anyway because the story can't continue if they don't know it. Don't give me the option to make these choices if you don't actually have a continuation for them. Terrible planning. Near infinite glitches, bugs, and visual clipping **** UI/UX leaves a lot to be desired. Sorting your inventory is mess. Tutorial pop ups appear and cover up important info but can't be dismissed until you leave the current screen you're trying to interact with. Objective indicators often lead you in the wrong direction if you enter another area. Dye color names are sometimes misleading. Random NPCs will prevent you from looting something that should be of no concern to them or should be rightfully yours to access. The learning curve for the sloppy combat mechanics is frustrating. Dashing really confuses the games logic often throwing a "can't reach this target" when you in fact can, and you just need to select the area next to it first.This game is truly a mess and undeserving of the praise it receives. A real shame because it could have been a 10/10 if Larian actually put the effort into it, but I suppose the bar for GOTY is low these days and easy profit is tempting. Seriously a shame.

This shift away from real-time action robs the game of the excitement and intensity that defined its predecessors.

This is tough to write because honestly, Act 1 and 2 make this game THE Game of the Year. Heck, I was ready to put it in my top 5 all time favorite games. I have 100+ hours in this game now and just loved the story and choices and the combat. And then Act 3 happened. I started having performance issues, I started having weird glitches were my companions would lose half their bodies and couldn't fight anymore, I've had 5 different quests completely bug out on me and even a main quest bug out that I can't even complete. Not only that, but the story choices of what is going on - the main bad guys and fights aren't as thought out as things were in the first 2 acts. It is very clear that Act 3 was completely rushed in my opinion to get the release out the door and does not have the same care that Acts 1 and 2 had. All of that enjoyment of Acts 1 and 2 to just come up against the frustrations in Act 3 killed my enthusiasm for this game. I know Larian will likely fix these issues as I suspect as more people start finishing the game they will see/hear this criticism - and quite possibly they already know this. But I can't in good faith recommend someone spend 80+ hours in a game and then just run up against game breaking bugs that won't allow them to finish the game they way they want to. That just feels pretty bad.

It's pretty to look at, and if you are really into Samurai stories/cinema you may enjoy this game for the experience of fighting like a samurai. Not being a hug fan of the genre, I found it very difficult to relate to the characters, and they definitely were not likable in my opinion. I didn't feel invested in the story and found it difficult to justify playing. The abilities that you get as you progress will slightly mix up your play style and the feel of the game but not enough. Enemies are almost exclusively mundane humans which is okay when you don't have a point of comparison. However, if you've played God of War, Demons Souls, The Last of Us, Returnal, or even Horizon Zero Dawn (all games with enemies and abilities that draw on supernatural sources of inspiration) then the enemies in this game will be quite bland by comparison. I may return to this game once I've exhausted all the other amazing and free games in the Play Station collection, but until then this purchase is nothing more than a regret now collecting dust in my game library.

The game is fundamentally a good RPG but not a good God of War. To me it has little in common with what makes a God of War game truly special. Colorful, fairy-tale-like worlds, a lack of gore and a toned-down Kratos just aren’t fun. Most of the boss fights were pretty mid. I also don’t like Atreus and the story in general. I really miss God of War 3 especially the old combat system. God of War Ragnarök is fine if you’re looking for an RPG but if you want a real God of War experience like in the old days stay away. A lot of the bosses from the side content are also completely over the top in terms of difficulty and balancing. You definitely don’t feel like the powerful Kratos from the old games anymore. Going for the platinum trophy wasn’t all that fun either.

I have been a massive fan of the God of War franchise playing almost every single game that Santa Monica Studio made only two games I have never play. Playing the playstation handheld and console version both the playstation 3 to playstation 5. Am just going to put on the table this is some of the best efforts I have seen from the developer of Santa Monica Studio every aspect of the game is just perfect the only problem is finding the problem with this game. Let's start with the story between Kratos and Atreus also known as Loki. I have never seen such a perfect story so well written the story of a man trying to put his past behind him trying to move forward and be a father again doing things right without violence is such a well put story. Pacing is bit inconsistent during some part of Angrboda sections is a bit drag out and cringe sometime maybe not for some but I find myself disliking Angrboda due to the fact that she is not really that likeable in my opinion and during some part of the sections its drag for too long and only some part is important like finding out the prophesy of kratos and having a deeper connection with Atreus. The story and how the game is serving it to you is just a masterpiece. I love that you get to play as Atreus sometimes and even get to partner up with different people throughout your journey. And you even get to pair up with Thor it's so awesome and fun. The music and song is just so well suited and I love love Bear McCreary for creating such a well put song. the direction that Santa Monica studio is going for this franchise is so well put from a man of revenge and anger that fuel his anger to kill those who wrong him and stand in his way to a father that is trying to put is life behind him and try to be a normal person Is such a well put innovative thinking but of course with the game that is this perfect in nearly every aspect of the game comes with flaws with is very hard to find and pin point down. The pacing is a bit inconsistent at the middle of the game and also the difficulty I found was not really that hard even though I play on god of war difficulty which is the hardest but it could be higher to tune for player who really wants the challenge. Enemy design and world map is very well detailed and bugs were never an issue and barely any bugs. Now with the rating am giving a 9 out of 10 a must play badge. By MarshMallow
A true successor. Great story, brutal gameplay, awesome graphics. Perfect in each aspect.

God of War: Ragnarök proves that Santa Monica Studio is not only capable of continuing the legacy of this iconic franchise, but elevating it to even greater heights. This sequel delivers a breathtaking cinematic experience, paired with refined gameplay and a rare emotional depth for an action **** evolution of the characters—especially the complex relationship between Kratos and his son Atreus—brings maturity and humanity to the story. Combat remains brutal and satisfying, with expanded tactical variety. The world design is incredibly detailed, and the epic score amplifies every moment.While a few segments feel slightly drawn out, the journey is well worth every minute. Ragnarök isn’t just a follow-up—it’s a peak moment in a series that redefined the action-adventure genre.Pros:Mature, emotionally resonant storyDeep, satisfying combat mechanicsStunning visuals and world-buildingRichly developed charactersCons:Some side quests feel repetitiveNarrative pacing slows down occasionallyVerdict:God of War: Ragnarök stands as one of the best games of this generation, and a fitting conclusion to Kratos’ Norse saga

Ragnarok is at least as good **** as GoW 2018. I put over 50 hours into this game and actually enjoyed doing as many side quests as possible because they were actually fun. The level design, puzzles and objectives were great. The graphics are excellent. The game feels good to play on the DualSense controller and the controls are very smooth. Walking and combat feels satisfying. The combat is very fun and doesn't feel grindy. The story is pretty good, though I didn't entirely comprehend it all. At times, the game felt more like a movie than a game, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. I really like the character Brok. The reviewers complaining about the game being woke are ridiculous, probably because there are a couple of black characters. Are they not allowed to be in video games?? Anyway, if there are any flaws about this game, I would say that the RPG elements, equipment menus and vast array of attacks and abilities can be a bit much to fully understand. There are numerous attack combos that you can unlock, but I only used a handful of attacks throughout the whole game because I can't remember 30+ different attacks which require various button combos. But again, you can progress just fine by sticking to a few favorite attacks. The game is not difficult, but just right, in my experience. I did think the voice acting was a bit cringey for certain characters. I am not really a fan of Atreus, to be honest. But at the end of the day, the game has a lot to offer in terms of exploration, side quests, fun, equipment and ability upgrades.

Great game, but a step down from God of War (2018). The sound design and voice acting are excellent, and the storytelling is strong — though the plot twists are predictable and lack excitement. Visually, the graphics and animations are solid, but there are some dated and rough-looking elements, like low-quality distant objects and even nearby textures, such as certain rocks. Lighting can be surprisingly poor at times, giving the game an outdated look. Most realms feel visually similar and lack distinctiveness, with some questionable design choices. The extended Atreus sections drag on and feel tedious. Combat is generally fun, but can become chaotic and occasionally unresponsive, especially when dodging. The lock-on camera is more frustrating than helpful. Progression feels somewhat unbalanced. Upgrading armor is harder than it should be, and weapons feel underpowered. Nearing the final story mission with 90% of the world explored, I still can't upgrade any armor past level 7 or my weapons beyond level 6–7. There’s also a sense of padding — the 12 berserker fights, for example, felt more exhausting than rewarding. Overall, while Ragnarok is a very good game, it doesn’t reach the impact and variety of its predecessor. God of War (2018) was a truly memorable experience, Ragnarok just doesn’t hit the same heights.

Game Review – A Masterpiece of Combat, Storytelling, and Character DevelopmentThis game delivers an outstanding experience, building on the intense and immersive combat mechanics that fans loved in the previous installment — now refined and expanded for even greater impact. The gameplay feels fluid and dynamic, offering a satisfying challenge through both mini-bosses and epic main-boss battles that are smartly distributed throughout the journey. What truly sets this game apart is its emotional depth and storytelling. The narrative is packed with dramatic, emotional, and epic moments, alongside unexpected twists that keep players fully engaged. The character development is remarkably well-crafted, with relationships evolving meaningfully over time, adding emotional weight to the journey. Equally impressive is the writing and design of the antagonists, particularly Thor and Odin. These characters are not just obstacles — they are complex, well-written figures who enrich the story with moral ambiguity and psychological depth. In conclusion, this game masterfully blends gameplay, story, and character development into a truly unforgettable experience. It stands as one of the finest games ever made — if not the finest — and sets a new benchmark for action-adventure storytelling.

God of War: Ragnarok is almost a great game. Interesting story, fun level design, good combat, fantastic bosses, excellent voice acting, decent pacing, great graphics, good sound design, good sound track... So why 6/10? This is a case where the sum is lesser than it's parts. Weak links in game design drag down what could be a fantastic game. Uninteresting objectives - the gameplay means less when you aren't interested in the outcome or the outcome is underwhelming. Poorly coordinated combat encounters - good combat system and controls mean little when the encounters are not well thought out. Meaningless exploration - the rewards for time spent searching make you feel like you should not be exploring in the first place. Inconsistent pacing - adrenaline filled boss fight to walking simulator. I'll add that I found the dialog lazy compared to the first game. This game continues the trend of gamers largely en masse accepting below average as masterclass. I'm not sure if my gaming peers are children with different ideas of what a good game can be or if they have underdeveloped/differing opinions but I cannot agree with the acclaim this game has received. I did not finish the game (I did 100% God of War, that game was overall much more enjoyable from the standpoints of my criticisms outlined in this review) and I would not recommend Ragnarok to the busy adult gamer who should spend their time and money on a higher quality product.

A funny thing happened while playing this top tier AAA game: I stopped having fun. The main culprit is the “Soulsification” of gameplay and its emphasis on difficulty that just shuts out older and slow players or players who are stressed for time who just don’t care about getting good. The gameplay itself is the problem with this game. The main issue is the parry mechanic. You can no longer simply block with a shield. Every block has to be perfectly timed with an enemy attack. Time it wrong and you are worse off than not blocking. The accessibility options will let you tweak enemy damage but not increase the parry window. A longer reaction window would also help with attacks that can’t be blocked and attacks that must be counter attacked with a shield attack. The first God of War game came out in 2005. It’s long overdue for this franchise make their games accessible to an aging player base. A minor enemy of fun in this game is the repeated backtracking to already explored areas for minor fetch quests. This is not an open world game and traversal is not fun. Some of the puzzles were not that fun either. I can see why folks like the climb anywhere mechanic in the latest Zelda games. That‘s enough negativity. The world, story, dialogue, and voice acting in this game are the best around. When people say they want single player games, they mean story telling and world building like this. You could take away all the combat and turn God of War into a story based game like “Detroit: Become Human”, and players would still love it. So all-in-all, I recommend this game with caveats. If you are a novice gamer or older gamer like myself, you might struggle to enjoy this game. With some tweaking, this could be a perfect 10/10 game. Right now, it just isn’t.

God of War Ragnarok: A Masterpiece of Storytelling, Combat, and Character Growth After completing God of War Ragnarok and its Valhalla DLC, I can confidently say that this game exceeded my expectations in every way. From the intense boss battles to the breathtaking animation and deeply emotional storytelling, Santa Monica Studio delivered an unforgettable experience that solidifies Kratos’ legacy. Combat & Boss Battles The battles in God of War Ragnarok are nothing short of epic. Every encounter feels weighty, tactical, and rewarding. Facing gods, beasts, and legendary warriors kept me engaged from start to finish. From the brutal confrontations with Thor and Odin to the shocking returns of Magni and Modi in Valhalla, every fight is designed to push Kratos to his limits. The DLC adds even more depth by making Kratos confront not just enemies, but his past self, leading to some of the most meaningful duels in the series. Animation & Visuals Visually, this game is a masterpiece. The level of detail in the environments, from the icy peaks of Midgard to the fiery ruins of Muspelheim, is breathtaking. Every animation—from Kratos’ brutal combat executions to Atreus’ swift archery—feels fluid and cinematic. Playing on PC via Steam, I was able to experience God of War Ragnarok in stunning high resolution, making every moment feel even more immersive. Story & Character Development What sets Ragnarok apart is its powerful storytelling. Kratos’ journey is no longer just about survival and vengeance—it’s about legacy, redemption, and change. Seeing Kratos evolve from the Ghost of Sparta into a leader and father figure willing to guide others was one of the most compelling aspects of the game. Atreus also grows significantly, forging his own path while still staying connected to his father. The introduction of new characters and the return of familiar ones, such as Sigrun and the Shield Maidens, enriches the world-building and lore. Final Thoughts God of War Ragnarok is more than just a game—it’s an experience. The seamless combination of action, mythology, and emotional storytelling makes it one of the greatest titles of this generation. With the Valhalla DLC, we get an even deeper dive into Kratos’ past, testing his resolve and forcing him to face the ghosts that still haunt him. If you haven’t played God of War Ragnarok, now is the time. And if you’ve already experienced it, let’s discuss! What were your favorite moments? What do you think is next for Kratos? Drop your thoughts in the comments!

God of War: Ragnarök is a continuous epic of God of War 2018, built on the same engine and carries on the great story of the first game... However, it's not as good in terms of Story as the first game. Gameplay: 10/10 Story: 8.5/10 Graphics: 9/10 Enjoyment: 9/10 Music: 9.5/10 Overall: 9/10 God of War: Ragnarök once again shines through with its outstanding combat, with fluid animations and finishers, it puts it above all other action games. Combine that with good world-building and storytelling, and you have an imposing cinematic action game. The puzzles are done much better in Ragnarök, they built upon the good mechanics they had in the base God of War and made the puzzles very intriguing and fun to complete. They also added more side content compared to the first game, which already had a lot. The music and themes of the characters are done to perfection. I have a few criticisms about the story. First, the voice actor for one character I cannot mention is not great, and it really does not match his character, but instead sounds like a pre-pubescent. God of War Ragnarök was, for me, an amazing and engaging experience from beginning to end.From the first moments, I felt that the narrative would be even more ambitious than in its predecessor.The relationship between Kratos and Atreus evolves in a very natural way, showing a father more willing to trust his son, but still fighting his own protective instincts.This dynamic is one of the highlights of the game.Each Kingdom of Yggdrasil has a striking visual identity, with very rich scenarios in detail and life.Midgard, now frozen, brings an oppressive atmosphere, while places like Vanaheim offer an explosion of colors and wild nature.The soundtrack only intensifies this immersion, with epic compositions that put you in the skin of a warrior facing colossal challenges. The combat is simply spectacular.The fluid transition between the leviathan ax, the chaos blades and the new elements brought to the kratos arsenal provides a huge tactical variety.Facing enemies with different strategies is never monotonous, especially in the fights against bosses - which, incidentally, are even more challenging and memorable. The story caught me.The weight of Kratos' choices and the journey of self -knowledge of the Atreus is conducted with mastery, addressing topics such as Legacy, Destiny and Redemption.I will not give spoilers, but the climax and outcome are exciting, leaving that taste of mission accomplished, but also a slight melancholy because an epic era may be reaching **** had to highlight a point that made me a little frustrated, would be the linearity of certain missions and some sections that seemed a little stretched without need.Still, this is a small detail against **** General, God of War Ragnarök was an unforgettable journey to me.It is the kind of game that not only delivers visceral action, but also a mature and touching narrative, proving once again that the series is at the top of the world of games.

Criticism - God of War: Ragnarok Note: 8/10 God of War: Ragnarok is an ambitious and epic sequence that expands the universe of Nordic mythology while deepening the journey of Kratos and Atreus.Developed by Santa Monica Studio, the game raises the narrative and the fight against new levels, but is not free of failures.The story is undoubtedly the highlight.The plot addresses the imminent Ragnarok and the intertwined destinations of Kratos, Atreus and the Nordic gods.The relationship between father and son is even more developed, with emotional moments that exploit confidence, legacy and difficult choices.Secondary characters, such as Freya, Thor, and Odin, are richly characterized, bringing unexpected depth and layers to the narrative.The gameplay is refined and satisfactory.The combat is brutal and dynamic, with the return of Leviathan ax and chaos blades, as well as new elements that maintain fresh experience.The puzzles are well designed, and the exploration in the nine kingdoms is rewarding, with beautifully detailed scenarios and a wide variety of enemies and bosses.However, the part involving the minds divides opinions.Playing as it is an interesting change of pace, but its gameplay is less impactful and less fluid than Kratos, which may break immersion at crucial times.In addition, its parallel history, although it is important to the general plot, may seem dragged on some parts, damaging the pace of the game.Despite these problems, God of War: Ragnarok is still an amazing experience, with a powerful story, impressive visuals and unforgettable combat.Note 8 reflects the grandeur of the game, but also recognizes that not all narrative and gameplay choices have been perfection.If you liked the previous title, Ragnarok is mandatory even with its imperfections.A journey that will certainly be marked in the memory of the players

God of War: Ragnarok is a masterpiece that perfectly balances deep lore with engaging gameplay. The way it builds on Norse mythology is incredible, weaving a story that feels both epic and deeply personal. Every interaction with the gods and creatures of the Nine Realms adds layers to the lore, making the world feel rich and **** gameplay is just as outstanding. The combat is fluid, brutal, and satisfying, with plenty of options to customize your playstyle. Whether you’re swinging the Leviathan Axe or summoning runic attacks, every fight feels dynamic and rewarding. Combined with jaw-dropping visuals and a perfectly paced story, Ragnarok is a game that’s as fun to play as it is to experience.

Pros - expanded 2018 combat system in all the right ways - breathtaking performances - fun exploration - higher difficulties highlight the best parts of the combat system - insanely better enemy variety compared to 2018 // Cons - the boat/sled exploration is made annoying by voice lines getting repeated every 10 seconds (every Mimir story has two sentences to catch the player up if interrupted, and those can last just long enough to not get anywhere before the new point of interest and then repeat again) // The follow up the incredible God of War 2018 had a lot to live up to. And it somehow exceeded every expectation I had for the game. Every aspect I liked about the 2018 game is better than before and it is not even close. The expanded combat with some of the skills from the previous entry becoming basic abilities is so much fun. New Runic Attacks and the use of the triangle button to add extra potential to every weapon pays off so much that by the first two hours it felt like something that was always a part of the 2018 formula. What aids this feeling is the expanded enemy variety. Several factions, with distinct abilities and bosses that are far more varied than the 2018 six flavors of troll. All of the enemies have clear attack patterns, reducing a lot of the 2018 screen clutter. All of the weapons being part of exploration is also a lot of fun. While the game still has that glued to the ground issue, the blades especially add some much needed briskness to movement. Then there is the story. This game does far more with its narrative than I ever expected. Going through the base game, it builds slowly until about chapter six. After that the game just does not let off the gas, ending in one of the most epic sequences I have ever played. And then comes Valhalla. A free piece of DLC that gives genuinely emotional redemption to Kratos. They cooked with this game. And they cooked hard. All in all, God of War Ragnarök should be a glowing standard to what sequels should be. Improvement on all fronts, with satisfying gameplay and narrative. Could not recommend this game any harder.

God Of War Ragnarök masterfully builds upon its predecessor, delivering an epic continuation of Kratos and Atreus's journey through Norse mythology. The game introduces a rich narrative filled with emotional depth, complex character development, and stunning visuals that draw players into its beautifully crafted **** gameplay mechanics are refined, offering a seamless blend of brutal combat and intricate puzzles. The addition of new abilities and weapons enhances the combat experience, allowing for a variety of playstyles. Additionally, there are moments where the narrative could have benefited from tighter editing.Overall, God of War Ragnarök is an extraordinary sequel that successfully expands upon its predecessor's legacy. With its compelling story, engaging gameplay, and stunning presentation, it stands as a must-play title for both fans of the series and newcomers alike.

It’s an unforgettable journey and a modern gaming classic – a testament to what happens when every piece ****, from the story to the visuals to the gameplay, is crafted with artistry and passion. A must-play for any fan of the genre and a defining moment for the medium itself.

God of War: Ragnarok continues the 2018 reboot's trend, which diverges significantly from the original trilogy. Earlier titles, known for their fast-paced combat, mythological depth, and Kratos' rage-fueled vengeance, set a high standard in the action-adventure genre. Ragnarok, while visually stunning and narratively rich, adheres to the more cinematic, story-driven approach. This shift in focus, with a slower pace and increased emphasis on character development, has alienated some long-time fans. The departure from the original formula is seen by some as diluting the essence that made God of War iconic, replacing relentless action with introspective storytelling. In summary, the current formula is perceived by some as detracting from the series' core appeal, overshadowing its legendary status with a different gameplay experience.

If there is a game that “improves upon perfection,” then this it is. God of War Raganrok is my favorite game of all time for a reason. It took what made God of War 2018 so good and somehow improved upon its predecessor in basically every fathomable aspect. The story was way more emotional and heavily weighted, the combat is a no brainer, the exploration is so much bigger with more areas to explore, the side quests are actually lore/story consistent unlike most of them from the 2018 title, and don’t even get me started on the Valhalla dlc. I'm amazed this game is such a step back from the previous game and everyone is giving it a pass. Yes, the traversal is all massively improved and combat has more depth and combos, but that's just enough to get through the game. The game is just as visually stunning as the previous one with some noticeable touch ups to textures, but some of the level design is just awful, especially Ironwood which is essentially a junkyard in a swamp with some grey and reddish purple but mostly piss yellow and diarrhea brown (all the while Atreus is saying "this is BEAUTIFUL!" But I guess some people like looking at a used public toilet that backed up a long time ago?) The voice acting is quite good and the characters feel like realistic versions of gods and demi gods at times, at other times it's not very good and even bad. But the writing and themes, my god. Imagine any political hot topic from global warming to European colonialism exploiting other races to the evils of WHALING. And that's just within the first few hours and it's not very subtle or smart, but instead incredibly preachy and incessant. Constantly hitting you over the head with these messages, and it only gets worse the longer you play the game. It's unbelievable. It's a shame too because some of these themes work with the story being told here, it's just HOW it's told to you that makes it annoying or, worse yet, boring. On my new game+ I just put the game on mute and turned off subtitles, game became that much better. There really is nothing wrong with the story itself, it's a solid follow up to what happened in the previous game with both Kratos's journey as a father now with more focus on Atreyu growing into his own legend, and ultimately how that all ties in with the overall arc of the gods of Aesgard trying to prevent Rägnarök. But these writers cobbled this **** together without any real cohesive vision and the final result is a preachy, long winded slog. Really disappointing.

When gameplay of God of War 2018 was released, I remember everyone being concerned about Atreus and worry about him in combat, or being the annoying kid character that distracts from the main story of Kratos. Those concerns were addressed by the devs as they explained that Atreus would only assist in combat and solving puzzles, not playable, and only added to bring a depth and gravity to the life of Kratos. And that is exactly what happened when you played tha game. However, in GOW Ragnarök, Atreus has become the main focus of the story and a playable character no one wanted. The most boring combat and forced story plots as a way to add a convoluted and unconvincing passing of the torch to the next generation at the expense of everything that made GOW 2018 so special...a disconnected father and son finding themselves and developing a genuine relationship by navigating the complexities of grief by losing the most important person in both their lives. Beautifully, utilizing small moments throughout the main beats of the story to equalize pace and add a realistic tone to character development without completely changing the characters themselves. But....Ragnork.....Atreus is an dumb and confused teenager who feeds whatever plot is needed for the convoluted story choices by the writers who obviously tried to cram every character mentioned in a google search for Nordic mythology. Lazy writing turning Kratos into an apologetic helicopter pilot needing to apologize for not understanding the perspective of his idiotic kid. We wanted God Of War and we got God of Angst. The devs and technical people who worked on this game get a 10/10. However, the story writers get a 5/10 for flicking their boogers at everyone who bought the game.

God of War Ragnarok is a masterpiece that seamlessly blends breathtaking visuals, immersive storytelling, and adrenaline-pumping gameplay into an unforgettable gaming experience. Building upon the success of its predecessor, this installment takes players on an epic journey through Norse mythology, where they assume the role of the formidable warrior, Kratos, once again.From the moment you step into the shoes of Kratos, you're immediately drawn into a world teeming with rich lore and vibrant characters. The game's narrative unfolds with cinematic flair, weaving together themes of redemption, sacrifice, and the complexities of fatherhood. Kratos' relationship with his son, Atreus, serves as the emotional core of the story, adding layers of depth and resonance to every encounter.Visually stunning landscapes and meticulously crafted environments breathe life into the realms of Norse mythology. From the towering peaks of Asgard to the depths of Helheim, each location is rendered with breathtaking detail, making exploration a feast for the senses. Dynamic weather effects and day-night cycles further enhance the immersion, creating a world that feels alive and constantly evolving.Combat remains the heart of the God of War experience, and Ragnarok delivers in spades. The fluid, responsive combat mechanics from the previous game are refined and expanded upon, offering a satisfying blend of brutal melee encounters and strategic prowess. Kratos' arsenal of weapons and abilities has been expanded, allowing for greater customization and playstyle diversity. Whether you prefer to unleash devastating combo attacks or rely on precise timing and parries, the combat system offers ample opportunities for mastery and experimentation.Beyond its captivating story and exhilarating gameplay, God of War Ragnarok excels in its attention to detail and commitment to immersion. From the haunting melodies of its orchestral score to the nuanced performances of its voice cast, every element comes together to create a truly immersive experience that resonates long after the credits roll. In conclusion God of war Ragnarok is a MUST PLAY FOR ANYONE and this game captures the essence of perfection

Title: A Mythological Masterpiece: God of War Ragnarök Review God of War Ragnarök, exclusively for the PlayStation 5, is a monumental achievement in video game storytelling, gameplay, and technical prowess. Santa Monica Studio has not only crafted a worthy successor to the critically acclaimed God of War (2018) but has elevated the series to new heights with this latest installment. Ragnarök transcends the boundaries of its genre, delivering an epic, emotionally charged journey through the Nine Realms that is as deeply moving as it is breathtakingly beautiful. From the moment the game begins, players are thrust into a world of unparalleled visual splendor. The PlayStation 5's capabilities are fully leveraged to bring the Nine Realms to life in staggering detail. From the frostbitten landscapes of Fimbulwinter to the lush, vibrant realms beyond, each environment is rendered with such precision and artistry that it's easy to become lost in the sheer beauty of the world. The character models, too, are incredibly lifelike, with expressive animations that convey emotion in a way that is profoundly impactful. The narrative of God of War Ragnarök is a masterclass in storytelling. Continuing the journey of Kratos and his son, Atreus, the game delves deeper into Norse mythology, weaving a tale of fate, family, and forgiveness that is both epic in scale and intimate in its exploration of character relationships. The writing is exceptional, with dialogue that captures the essence of each character and their struggles, driving the story forward in compelling and unexpected ways. Gameplay in Ragnarök is as refined as it is exhilarating. Combat is fluid and satisfying, with a perfect balance of strategy and brutality that the series is known for. Kratos' arsenal of weapons and abilities, along with Atreus' growing prowess in battle, offers players a plethora of ways to engage foes, from towering giants to the gods themselves. The addition of new abilities and the refinement of existing mechanics make every encounter a thrilling test of skill. The game's design, from the sprawling open-world exploration to the intricate puzzle-solving, is executed with precision and creativity. Each realm offers unique challenges and secrets to uncover, ensuring that exploration is always rewarded with meaningful discoveries. The pacing is impeccable, seamlessly blending intense combat, exploration, and narrative moments to keep players engaged from start to finish. God of War Ragnarök's score is another standout aspect of the game. The music beautifully encapsulates the emotional depth and epic scope of the journey, enhancing every moment with a soundtrack that is as memorable as it is moving. Sound design, too, is top-notch, with the clash of weapons, the roar of monsters, and the serene quiet of the realms immersing players fully into the world. In terms of innovation, Ragnarök sets a new standard for accessibility in gaming. The game includes an extensive array of accessibility features, ensuring that players of all abilities can experience the story and gameplay. This commitment to inclusivity is commendable and sets an example for the industry. In conclusion, God of War Ragnarök is not just a game; it's a landmark achievement in interactive storytelling and game design. It is a journey that will resonate with players long after the credits roll, a testament to the artistry and craftsmanship of Santa Monica Studio. With its stunning visuals, masterful narrative, exhilarating gameplay, and emotional depth, God of War Ragnarök is a masterpiece of the medium and an essential experience for any PlayStation 5 owner. It is, without doubt, one of the finest games ever crafted.

I thoroughly enjoyed playing this game, this is an all-time great, and will leave a lasting impression. The story of God of War Ragnarok is nothing short of epic. It strikes a perfect balance, avoiding excessive drama while still providing ample room for character development. The integration of side quests into the main narrative is seamless, enhancing the overall experience and immersing players in a rich world. From a technical standpoint, the game is a marvel. The rock-solid 60fps frame rate ensures smooth gameplay, and the stunning graphics, even in performance mode, showcase the game's visual prowess. It's a treat for the eyes, which further enhances the immersive nature of the game. The soundtrack and voice acting in God of War Ragnarok are top-notch. The serious tone of the music and the performances successfully elicit emotional responses and keep your heart racing throughout the game. The balance struck between intensity and believability is remarkable. There were a few drawbacks, however. The combat system, in particular, seemed to try too hard to emulate the style of Souls games. It placed heavy emphasis on pattern recognition and punished players for not immediately knowing an enemy's attack patterns. Once you familiarize yourself with these patterns though, the challenge decreases significantly, often rendering bosses ineffective against an experienced player. Overall God of War Ragnarok delivers an exceptional gaming experience. The engaging story, technical excellence, and captivating audio elements make it a truly memorable adventure. Although the combat system may have its drawbacks, it doesn't detract significantly from the overall enjoyment of the game. I highly recommend God of War Ragnarok to anyone seeking an epic and immersive experience.

For this reason, along with the final cutscene teasing a conflict with Thor, I was very excited for a sequel. After 43 hours, I finally finished GoW:R in April of 2024 (I was late to the party this time, yes). I'm happy to say it met my expectations and definitely did not disappoint. The good: The highlights were the stellar, jaw-dropping, bar-raising, graphics and environment detail/composition, as well as the gripping story coursing through the veins of the game's grandiose cutscenes. Ragnarok produces many memorable moments, just as its predecessor did. The combat feels visceral and impactful. It is familiar to returning players, while making a few adjustments and adding a new cool weapon. They also seem to have listened to the complaints concerning enemy/boss variety, as this time around there are many more boss types. An underrated aspect of God of War in my opinion is the voice acting, firstly, its great that many voice actors returned to the recording booths for this one, and secondly, the voice actors of Brok, Thor, Mimir, and Kratos are just so damned talented and memorable! Truly I love so many of them, I must give praise where it is due, Santa Monica have an eye for hiring unique and fitting voice actors. It's up there with the uncharted and red dead series for me. The same can be said about the story, this series and kratos' progression is legendary in video games for me, one of the best, most iconic, fleshed out stories. What could have been improved: While GoW: Ragnarok is great, there are a many remarks i'd like to make. No game is perfect, here are some things that slightly bothered me during my playthrough: I feel like you can't zoom in on the map enough. Secondly, although the combat felt great, I personally felt like Atreus was a little stiff in a literal sense and in terms of what he can do in the players' hands, and despite a third new, cool weapon, it added a layer of uncertainty whenever I picked a weapon (will I equip the one I want? and will this one be the most effective?). It should have been made more clear which weapons are more effective against which enemies. And while the combat is gory, and, as I have said before, visceral, it seems counter productive and looks underwhelming to have enemies immediately transform into leaves and vanish. Frankly, I struggle to rationalise the choice: It takes away from the gore, I doubt it was for memory/processing reasons, and potentially it could have been due to the will to not obstruct gameplay, but I can think of many ways to reduce such problems besides just making the vanquished vanish. look, I just think the timing and visuals are unbefitting. However, in all honesty, it is not a big deal. Furthermore, some faces seemed a bit uncanny (like Atreus and Freya) and out of place in what is otherwise an impeccable looking game. ragnarok was kind of underwhelming for me, maybe a bit more footage of the wolves and close ups of the Thor vs Jormungandr fight and odin's pov while all the chaos is happening and his emotions and preparation and a cool shot of asgard's soldiers all lined up and advancing, I mean there was so much more they could have added to make it more epic and memorable, cuz all i remember was seeing the rogue valkyries flying towards the walls of Asgard and Jörmungandr in the distance and Fenrir making a brief appearance in front of me/kratos & Atreus... I'm not sure why it was so important to focus on the protagonists during the whole war. Freyr and freya's involvement felt kinda supressed... What I disliked: For some reason, I was really struggling at times with staying focused on the world, with how close to the camera kratos was. I wish there was a FOV/camera distance slider in the settings. My second and final real complaint is how interruptive Atreus tends to be during puzzle-solving moments. I'm only realising now that it only got better in the second half because there were less puzzles, perhaps because I was focusing more on the Story and finishing the game, or it was by design, bizarrely. Conclusion: Despite my criticisms, it is a dream sequel. builds upon the first, and the first was already a masterpiece. The characters evolve even more, the story and characters are flesh out even more, and the same can be said about the gameplay and graphics. As fun, memorable, emotional, gory, mythical and nordic as ever. They listened to the criticisms, enemies are more varied. lacking skill tree n camera felt too zoomed in and a lot of immersion breaking lines. the camera is unsettlingly close. I don't remember have issues with the previous entry, but this time I really wished there were FOV/camera distance options. Also, enemies turning into leaves is anti-climactic and counter-productive. I give GoW:R an 87/100.

Ragnarok is an incredible, emotional and captivating adventure, with dramatic moments in the story, although it also contains intense action, to the point that we will question whether the work is a movie or a video game for real, everything is perfect, thanks to the excellent director’s cut and actors staging: we have brilliant cinematics. Being in this way a great sequel, providing one of the best games of the entire saga, culminating its story. Ragnarok manages to surpass his predecessor in many aspects, the level designs were totally improved, leaving behind the typical linear paths, thus expanding its borders, now with much larger and open areas (very extensive by the way) full of platforms and verticality. Exploration is another strength, since now we have a lot of secondary content with great quality, as interesting as if it were the same main adventure. The combat within the gameplay are improved points, now with a greater amount of skills and weaponry we will be able to face greater numbers of enemies, all varied in designs, with excellent AI, providing a fresh air and leaving behind the repetition of the same enemy changing in color. Special mention to the brilliant level bosses, now we will find much more, with their own strategies and moments that will take our breath away, giving us long fights and extraordinary sequences. The music maintains the same size as its predecessor, a high quality level, each area with its particular rhythm, enveloping tones and creating a great atmosphere, recreating the ideal momentum. In summary, there is a lot of continuity in this GOW Ragnarok, it is very conservative in many aspects, but thanks to the expansion of its mapping, it offers greater depth in its missions and quests, providing a much improved exploration or rewards, all this makes feels it is a more complete product in global content than its predecessor. Graphically a wonder, pure art and horse power muscle, squeezing the qualities of the console to the edge, great performance! I am ready for the next chapter!

An evolution, but only in technical matters The 2018 God of War was a game that really affected me, I was a fan of the franchise before, but I wasn't that much of a fan, after the fourth game I went crazy about this game, it was incredible, the story, the graphics, the ost , everything, so I was expecting great things from this one, but it didn't deliver as much as I expected. On the technical side I have nothing to complain about, just praise, what a beautiful game, it has evolved a lot from what was already good, the gameplay is much more satisfying and fluid, many more enemies, other completely different kingdoms and the old ones have also been reworked, You can see how much effort they put into it and how much care they had when they were producing this game. But not everything is rosy, the story took a nosedive and the further it went, the more it fell. It's kind of sad to say this, but it needs to be said, this game has a more epic feel compared to its predecessor, trying to make you vibrate and say: "I've been waiting for this", but that's it, the logical sense and the game's coherence fails a lot, it seems like they worried a lot about how badass it would be and didn't worry about how well written it is, some things happen very quickly, others take much longer than they should, the side-quests that in the previous one I I thought they were fun, they didn't catch my attention in this one, I did at most about 4 of them, the new characters are not as interesting as the old ones and are very little developed, the boss fights are well done, but there are so many of them in the game that some of them were supposed to be more important or more epic and are left aside. Despite all this, I highly recommend this game, especially if you like the franchise, or if you liked the previous one, it made me cry, vibrate, scream, jump, get emotional and if you play it, I bet you'll feel the same
