God of War Ragnarok is an Action-Adventure game and it came out in 9 November 2022 for consoles (Ps4) and (Ps5). The game refers about the adventure of two main characters, which are the protagonists of the game Kratos(father) and Atreas(son) after the God of War (2018), where they are still trying to survive but now the fimbulwinter where it has arrived after the death of Baldur. On the other hand, Kratos is trying to protect his son again, as every father does from very dangerous monsters and hostile gods that are threats to his son, but he is not seeking for war and vengeance like he did when he was young and trying to avoid any possible conflict with gods through their adventure. Moreover, the narration of the game is incredibly emotional with it's own shocking and exciting moments, apart from this every character has it's own shocking character development with a lot of upheavals and suspicions, as well as it gives a powerful variety of emotions and how their development and their choices impacts their own future and other gods future. The technical field of the game ensures it's settings very well with a huge impact on perfomance and quality, however we can also mention about the audio of the game and how all of it's components connected together to make the best possible experience for the player, for example every character has it's own theme, and also how precised they have made sound effects for action moments and emotional and all of that. Now, I want to say a few things about the mechanics of the game and how they are using them in order to make the game more difficult for the player. First of all, it has different difficulty modes like for players that want to experience just the story of the game, another mode with slight focus on combat and two more modes that are for more experienced God of War players. Also, it's character has different capabilities and abilities on it's own skill tree, where you can modify your own action moves, and you can add different runes like on an RPG game to upgrade all of your armor and weapons. That was my review about that game and how I felt everything that were happening on that game. I have really enjoyed the game from the first minute to the last minute of the game, because I have played the previous god of war and I was really waited for the next one so long.

I absolutely loved this game, it builds on Kratos’ character more and beautifully builds on his character further. It build and expands on everything its previous instalment did and by doing so made everything better. Atreus is his own character and it opens the door for more possibilities in the franchise and there is satisfaction within his character in the story. The gameplay is amazing, combat has never felt so challenging in previous instalments and the bosses are the best in the franchise. The variety of armour, weapons and abilities makes combat so immersive and unique to your own play style. The story is amazing and the graphics are some of the best at this very moment. Kratos has the best face model in gaming history at the moment closely followed by Aloy in the Horizon franchise. The voice acting and performances are amazing and it’s understandable why Christopher Judge got the award for best performance back in The Game Awards. New faces in God of War’s story definitely felt memorable and satisfying, Scott Porter’s Heimdall was a personal favourite of mine and was one of the best characters in the game. There is very little to complain about when it comes to the game other than its few linear levels which felt a little tedious. The story has a slow pace to continue with its cinematic feel so it shouldn’t be rushed and you should be patient with the game. I love this game but it’s a bit sad this decreases it replay ability but nonetheless I still love this game for that. Although this may sound contradicting I think the lack of replay ability is a good thing since it simply avoids the game being too repetitive since as a person who platinumed the game and 100% every single realm, it does become very tedious over time and although exploration is amazing it’s still repetitive going place to place. Another small complaint I had was that when playing new game plus, the game thinks that you don’t have the spear and blades and therefore cinematic scenes had Kratos picking up literally nothing and blowing up rocks with the spear or throwing the spear in necessary areas isn’t possible until when the game thinks you get it. These are just small complaints however and it didn’t ruin my experience that much. Overall the game is masterful although it’s tiny nitpicks did make the game that bit tedious.

God of War Ragnarok is a magnificent sequel that addresses many of the weaknesses of its predecessor. Notably, it has significantly expanded the variety of enemies and introduced epic boss battles that enhance the overall gaming experience. The quality of side activities has seen an improvement, although there are still some rather inconsequential "spirit quests" that could have been omitted. Even after completing the main story, there is ample post-credits content and challenges to engage players who crave more. The optional foes provide a satisfying level of challenge and enjoyment. However, the hunting of ravens could have been omitted without detriment.From a narrative perspective, the game is a success. The plot is exciting and emotionally engaging, and the characters are interesting with their motivations being easily understandable. All in all, it offers a magnificent gaming experience that stands out. I'm eager to see how the future unfolds for our father-son duo.

God of War: Ragnarök is a worthy successor to the 2018 masterpiece. The game delivers a similarly thrilling experience, with Kratos and Atreus continuing their epic journey. The platinum trophy is as fantastic as its predecessor, challenging yet rewarding for completionists. The Steinbjorn armor is the best, proving its worth countless times in tough battles. The heartwarming ending ties up the saga beautifully, leaving a lasting impression. Beyond the main story, there's an abundance of post-game content, ensuring you won't want to put it down. It's so beautifully crafted that even after achieving the platinum, I couldn't resist starting a New Game+ to experience the 100% walkthrough all over again. Overall, "God of War: Ragnarök" earns a perfect 10/10. It's a remarkable achievement in gaming, delivering an unforgettable adventure that lives up to its predecessor's legacy. The combination of storytelling, visuals, and gameplay makes it an essential experience for any gamer.

God of War: Ragnarok, the highly anticipated sequel to the 2018 masterpiece, continues to shine in both its storytelling and visual prowess. While there haven't been significant changes in graphics or gameplay, I didn't expect any, nor did I necessarily want them. However, in my opinion, the story is expertly extended, and the Ragnarok theme is seamlessly integrated into the world of God of War.I eagerly immersed myself in this epic journey, spending hours on end exploring the world, completing the story, and finishing all the side quests. I was immensely proud to earn the Platinum trophy, a testament to how engrossing the game is. It's a clear recommendation for any aficionado of immersive storytelling.Once again, just like its predecessor, I found myself yearning for even more exploration of the Norse mythology. Therefore, I hold out hope for a DLC that will grant us the opportunity to delve deeper into this rich and captivating **** summary, God of War: Ragnarok is a worthy successor that continues to excel in storytelling and graphics. It offers a compelling and immersive experience that is sure to satisfy fans of the series and anyone who loves a good story. Here's to hoping for more adventures.
